text: havock hi everyone
Anthony Fantan oh here the Internet's
trashiest music nerd here with something
that's going to take you guys off no no
it's not a rap review takes you guys off
more than that it's a metal review Havok
is a denver band that proudly relives
the sounds of old-school thrash metal
and I'm not a thrash expert I don't
pretend to be I know my early Exodus my
early big for Bam Bam Bam Bam and I also
like a lot of crossover acts too like
DRI suicidal tendencies and crow bags
and for me Havoc's time up is just as
enjoyable as some of thrash metals
classics I listen to times up because I
want to listen to time is up not because
I want to get nostalgic and think of
peace cells or Master of Puppets
like any good thrash record this thing
is an overwhelming dose of sonic
testosterone because when this thing is
on I want to punch stuff I want to run
around I want to climb on things I want
to blow things up the energy on this
thing is non freaking stopped for the
most part and maybe that's almost to a
fault because even some of thrashes best
records had a slower moment of to some
kind of semblance of balladry you know
like a breather a break but pretty much
every tune here is a lean and mean three
to five minute thrash fest the song DOA
has some pretty nice harmonized guitar
solos in trowing the song and the title
track takes a little while to take off
but every other song here hits hard and
hits fast like a blitzkrieg or like a
thrash krieg which is fitting because
some of the lyrics here are about war
international
war and also two-faced scumbags and
throwing your life away because you're
living too fast during some of these
lyrical moments I feel like the the
frontman David Sanchez is like singing
directly to me and it kind of freaks me
out for a second like on time is up
where he's like take a number and have a
seat we'll be with you shortly not only
is that awesome but I kind of feel like
he's somehow figured out how to channel
Dave Mustaine or something and I love
David Sanchez vocals not only because of
his vocal delivery but just the way his
voice sounds it's like this high-pitched
raspy kind of thing in a way it kind of
sounds like a bottle rocket going off or
maybe a more intense version of overkill
and every once in a while he'll pull out
this high-pitched wail that's very King
Diamond desk so the vocals do come off
versatile because they do everything
well whether they're shouting or talking
or singing or doing these really big
gang vocals that emphasize the hook from
time to time and as far as mix and
recording and sound goes I really can't
fault this record on much of anything
maybe the guitars are a little too loud
maybe the bass could be brought up in
the mix I mean I know for example I
loved the fact that the bass brought so
much counterpoint on another modern
thrash record vector's black future even
though I don't get much of that here the
guitar tone is still really nice and the
drums on this thing are extremely just
pounding an intricate I mean the
drummer's always thrown in all sorts of
fills and yet he never loses track of
the groove or anything like that back to
the guitar one thing we need to talk
about with the guitar the solos on this
thing which play a huge part in thrash
metal they're all very tight straight to
the point
flashy while they're there but they
don't devour the entire song Banshee
note bends and just a flawless sweet
picking and these whammy bar whales that
sometimes kind of sound like a laser
melting my brain my only other complaint
is that there's not really a break on
here so a lot of the tracks
this thing can come off kind of say me
say me in terms of blueprint Wow even
though the tools the havoc uses on this
album are tried-and-true that doesn't
mean they don't use them well like you
know juggling the art of juggling is
ancient but if you came across somebody
juggling grenades and and chainsaws
would you say of juggling so old it's
been done whatever I really love this
album and I don't think you need to be
an old-school thrash metal aficionado to
enjoy it
I think this LP goes far far far beyond
nostalgia if you enjoy music that has
really intense drumming great grooves
and guitar riffs technical guitar solos
and a ton of aggression then this is
where you want to be I'm feeling a
strong eight to a light nine on this
record I had a hell of a time listening
to it it was fun every single time I
went through the album can't wait to
listen to it again
Anthony Fantana havoc time is up
forever
